name: funeral rites

attributes.attribute: speed on their way to the Otherworld
prevent hanging about to bother the living

sources: MacCulloch, J. A. The Religion of the Ancient Celts. London: Constable, 1911.
Monaghan, Patricia. The Encyclopedia of Celtic Mythology and Folklore. Checkmark Books, 2008.
text: Ancient Celtic funeral rites were typically observed through burials, rather than cremation or exposure. Ogham writing-carved stones may have been used to mark particular graves, although they were not limited to those of lower status. Grave-goods, such as chariots, coins, ornaments, and weapons, were commonly deposited in the graves along with the dead—likely meant for use in the Otherworld. Evidence indicates that rulers may have undergone human sacrifice, as their skulls were often found detached from their bodies, likely through decapitation. Both archaeological and textual examples indicate a belief that the dead could return to trouble the living; therefore, some funeral rites aimed to prevent that from happening. For instance, binding the feet of the corpse was thought to ensure the body would not wander. Later, customs changed to keep the feet free, so the dead could more easily move into the Otherworld and refrain from haunting the living.
